utterances: Let's talk about a fab lab.
Is this really a set of tools that I can use anywhere, you know, in my shop, or how far along are you?
What can I do with your fab lab?
That's the real surprise.
The fab labs are the analog of the minicomputers in the history of the PC, and so I thought they were quick hacks, but for about $20,000 now, you can create modern technology.
So it's my favorite kind of prediction about the future.
It's really a statement about the present.
Well, let's talk about the actual tools.
What kind of tools are we talking about here?
Is it a ""Star Wars"" transporter, or is it something a little more basic?
Sure, Clinton wasn't as new on the scene as Obama, but even Ronald Reagan running for re-election at age 73 managed to run as the candidate of change.
And, says Mellman, Clinton was also out-organized by Obama.

After a disappointing third place finish in Iowa, she bounced back in New Hampshire but couldn't do more than tie Obama on Super Tuesday, when he focused his efforts on smaller, mostly red states, states that she for some reason ignored.
The Clinton campaign acted as if they didn't know the rules, acted as if only large states counted.
And the truth is they came out fairly even in delegates out of the large states and allowed themselves to get creamed in smaller states, and that's really where Obama built up his delegate lead.
The Clinton camp made another false assumption - they thought the race would be wrapped up by February 5th.
Oh, we all did.
You know, we all did.
Pollster Stan Greenberg worked for Bill Clinton in 1992.
He says the Hillary Clinton team was tough and experienced but not flexible.
They were not willing to move to a second plan - plan B - until after they were out of money and after they were deep in a hole on, you know, elected delegates.
Plan B, which worked for Clinton in the later primaries like Ohio and Pennsylvania, was full-throated populism.
Clinton became a tenacious, gritty fighter for the crowds of working-class voters who became her base of support.
Well, you've never been invisible to me.
I've been fighting for you my entire life.
(Soundbite of cheering)
Democratic strategist Bill Carrick, also neutral this year, says that approach might have saved her if there were more votes left to be won.

I don't think it was until really when it was almost too late to reverse the outcome that she found her own voice - which was as a tribune for hard-working people and blue-collar voters, which she's done quite effectively.
But it was very late in the game.

And, says Carrick, there was another quirk of fate that hurt Clinton: Michigan and Florida, two huge states, took themselves off the playing field by breaking the rules instead of remaining on the calendar as originally scheduled in mid-February.
Once again, calendar is destiny in primary politics, and the Michigan decision to try to go early was a disaster for her.
The Florida decision was a disaster for her.
It would have been much better if they had stayed inside the calendar, where they would have really helped her.

But to Hillary Clinton supporter Bob Kerrey, who actually ran for president in 1992 and lost the nomination to Bill Clinton, all that pales in comparison to a much bigger, much simpler reason for Hillary's troubles.
She's running against a phenomenal candidate, a man who's, I would say, a better candidate than anything her husband faced in '92 or '96.
I'm not sure Bill Clinton could have beaten Barack Obama.
Every mistake that she made, if she had not been running against Barack Obama, wouldn't even be a footnote.
They're exaggerated.
They're magnified because he was out-raising her.
Because he was drawing enormous crowds.
Because he kept getting better.
And now, Obama is less than 70 delegates away from the nomination and Clinton is left making hopeful declarations like this one...
I'm going to keep making our case until we have a nominee, whoever she may be.
(Soundbite of cheering)
An extraordinary reversal of fortune for a candidate who seemed unbeatable less than six months ago.
Mara Liasson, NPR News, Washington.
It is one of human history's greatest mysteries: Stonehenge, the prehistoric stone monument in the southern English countryside.
Archaeologists and anthropologists have theorized that Stonehenge was built as a place of sun worship, because the sun aligns with the stones on the summer and winter solstice.
Or it could be a sacred burial ground or an astronomical observatory.
Now a team of scientists has begun the first archaeological dig at Stonehenge in more than 40 years, and it could lead to a new understanding of this ancient rock circle.
Lead archaeologist Professor Timothy Darvill is at the dig site.
Hello, there.
Hello, Andrea.
How are you?
Good.
So, where are you?
What does the dig look like right now?
Well, I'm actually standing inside the circle right next to one of the great trilithons in the middle.
And I'm sheltering a little bit because it's rather windy this afternoon and I wouldn't like the telephone to make too much noise.
And just in front of me I've got the excavation.
It's a piece of keyhole surgery really.
This is a very sacred site to many people, but English heritage have allowed us to dig just this one small hole.
It's about two-and-a-half meters by three-and-a-half meters so it's a nice area.
Isn't it a little scary or maybe awe-inspiring to dig up ground at Stonehenge?
Well, one feels the weight of responsibility on our shoulders because nobody's been allowed to dig here for nearly 50 years.
And the research questions have been piling up and finally we've been allowed to start exploring one or two of them.
Now, I understand that you have your own theory as to why Stonehenge was built, what it was for.
Indeed.
It's not necessarily different in the sense that it rules the others out.
But what struck us as really rather important is the way in which the monument changes its character when they bring in about 80 stones from the west of Wales.
They're not the ones that you see when you first look at the site because those are quite local stones - they're very large stones.
But in amongst those large stones are these so-called bluestones.
And these are the thing that make Stonehenge special because from the moment they arrive, the site becomes unique.
Now, what they eat and drink when the Ethiopian Christmas finally arrives on January 7 is traditionally doro wat - poultry pieces drowned in rich red sauce.
Abebe's wife, Shitaye, explains that the Christmas doro wat is bit different.
You have to slaughter a rooster - not a hen - and carve it into exactly 12 pieces representing the 12 disciples.
Yeah.
The drumstick and the thigh, the breasts, the wings...
The wings are each cut in two, plus the neck and the back make 12.
Add 12 hard-boiled eggs - some say that that symbolizes eternity - no beginning or end.
But eternity is what it can feel like to make the sauce.
You have to simmer down nine pounds of chopped onion with a chili called berbere.
To prepare that onion - I mean, to make it ready, to make it tender, it takes, like, four to five hours.
But it's funny because all these people coming into the restaurant - they say, OK, I'll have one doro wat, and you make it.
But it's such a special food for you.
It is very special for us.
But that special specialness is lost on the people.
Yeah.
If you do it every day, it is true.
But our guests are very special for us.
Nice save, Shitaye.
Nice save.
Now, at precisely 2:45 p.m., when the break fast can begin, Abebe reemerges with a plate of spongy sour flatbread called injera.
There's a generous dollop of shiro, a chickpea and white bean dish with 11 ingredients, nine of which are spices.
And there are other scoops of lentils, kale and other greens.
OK, can we bite?
Yeah.
Let's bite.
Yes, please.
We are through now.
It is, I can say, the most delicious fasting food I've ever consumed.
Gregory Warner, NPR News, Nairobi.
Roberto Gomez Bolanos or Chespirito, as he was known by millions of fans, died at his home in Cancun, Mexico on Friday.
Bolanos was one of Latin America's most beloved comedic actors and writers, entertaining generations of adults and children during his nearly 60-year career.
NPR's Nathan Rott has this remembrance.

In English, Chespirito roughly means little Shakespeare - a fitting nickname for Roberto Gomez Bolanos because the Mexico City-born artist wrote hundreds of television shows, 20 films and countless theater productions during his career, and also because of his stature and size.
He cast himself as a small boy in one of his most famous shows.
